nationalParks.name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
nationalParks.description: Renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture.

nationalParks.name: Grand Canyon National Park
nationalParks.description: Iconic for its immense size and its intricate and colorful landscape, the park offers unparalleled vistas of the canyon's layers of red rock.

nationalParks.name: Zion National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for Zion Canyon's steep red cliffs, Zion National Park also features forest trails along the Virgin River that flows to the Emerald Pools.

nationalParks.name: Yellowstone National Park
nationalParks.description: The first national park in the U.S. and widely held as the first in the world, known for its wildlife and its many geothermal features, especially Old Faithful geyser.

nationalParks.name: Rocky Mountain National Park
nationalParks.description: Features majestic mountain views, mountain lakes, and a variety of wildlife in diverse environments from wooded forests to mountain tundra.

nationalParks.name: Yosemite National Park
nationalParks.description: Famous for its giant, ancient sequoias, and for Tunnel View, the iconic vista of towering Bridalveil Fall and the granite cliffs of El Capitan and Half Dome.

nationalParks.name: Acadia National Park
nationalParks.description: Home to the rugged coastline of Maine, woodland, rocky beaches and glacier-scoured granite peaks such as Cadillac Mountain, the highest point on the United States' East Coast.

nationalParks.name: Grand Teton National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for its stunning mountain landscapes, alpine lakes, and abundant wildlife, including the towering Grand Teton.

nationalParks.name: Joshua Tree National Park
nationalParks.description: Characterized by rugged rock formations and stark desert landscapes. Named for the region's bristled Joshua trees, the park straddles the cactus-dotted Colorado Desert and the Mojave Desert.

nationalParks.name: Olympic National Park
nationalParks.description: Encompasses diverse ecosystems from the Pacific coastline to rainforests and glacier-capped mountains.

nationalParks.name: Glacier National Park
nationalParks.description: Named for its prominent glacier-carved terrain and remnant glaciers descended from the ice ages, it's home to diverse wildlife and many lakes.

nationalParks.name: Cuyahoga Valley National Park
nationalParks.description: Preserves and reclaims the rural landscape along the Cuyahoga River between Akron and Cleveland. Known for its waterfalls, rolling hills, and trails.

nationalParks.name: Indiana Dunes National Park
nationalParks.description: Features over 15 miles of Lake Michigan shoreline and 15,000 acres of beaches, dunes, marshes, swamps, and prairies.

nationalParks.name: Hot Springs National Park
nationalParks.description: Hot Springs National Park, located in central Arkansas, is renowned for its historic bathhouses and thermal springs, which have been a source of healing and relaxation for centuries.

nationalParks.name: Bryce Canyon National Park
nationalParks.description: Famous for its hoodoos, odd-shaped pillars of rock left standing from the forces of erosion, Bryce Canyon offers spectacular views from sunrise to sunset.

nationalParks.name: Shenandoah National Park
nationalParks.description: Shenandoah National Park is known for its spectacular vistas along the Skyline Drive, rolling hills, waterfalls, and forests.

nationalParks.name: Haleakalā National Park
nationalParks.description: Covers the dormant Haleakalā Volcano and surrounding landscapes. Known for its stunning sunrises, diverse ecosystems, and unique geological features.

nationalParks.name: Capitol Reef National Park
nationalParks.description: Named for the white domes and Navajo Sandstone cliffs that resemble the U.S. Capitol building, Capitol Reef is known for its colorful canyons, ridges, buttes, and monoliths.

nationalParks.name: Badlands National Park
nationalParks.description: Features striking geologic deposits that contain one of the world's richest fossil beds. Ancient mammals such as the rhino, horse, and saber-toothed cat once roamed here.

nationalParks.name: Everglades National Park
nationalParks.description: The largest tropical wilderness of any kind in the U.S., known for its vast and varied ecosystems, including mangrove forests, sawgrass marshes, and pine flatwoods.

nationalParks.name: Sequoia National Park
nationalParks.description: Famous for its giant sequoia trees, including the General Sherman Tree, the largest tree on Earth.

nationalParks.name: Death Valley National Park
nationalParks.description: Holds the record for the hottest place on earth, offering desolate and yet strikingly beautiful desert landscapes.

nationalParks.name: Saguaro National Park
nationalParks.description: Named for the large saguaro cactus, symbolizing the American West.

nationalParks.name: Canyonlands National Park
nationalParks.description: Offers visitors a view of the colorful landscape eroded into countless canyons, mesas, and buttes by the Colorado River.

nationalParks.name: White Sands National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for its dramatic landscape of rare white gypsum sand dunes.

nationalParks.name: Biscayne National Park
nationalParks.description: Protects a rare combination of aquamarine waters, emerald islands, and coral reefs.

nationalParks.name: Theodore Roosevelt National Park
nationalParks.description: Celebrates the legacy of the 26th President for his enduring contributions to the conservation of our national resources.

nationalParks.name: Mammoth Cave National Park
nationalParks.description: The world's longest known cave system, with more than 400 miles explored.

nationalParks.name: Kings Canyon National Park
nationalParks.description: Home to some of the deepest canyons in the United States and the giant sequoias.

nationalParks.name: Wind Cave National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for its complex and intricate cave system and mixed-grass prairie on the surface.

nationalParks.name: Glacier Bay National Park
nationalParks.description: A highlight of Alaska's Inside Passage and part of a 25-million acre World Heritage Site.

nationalParks.name: Crater Lake National Park
nationalParks.description: The deepest lake in the United States, known for its vivid blue color and water clarity.

nationalParks.name: Big Bend National Park
nationalParks.description: Offers a diverse environment of desert, mountains, and river that supports a variety of plants and wildlife.

nationalParks.name: Petrified Forest National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for its large deposits of petrified wood, part of a larger desert ecosystem.

nationalParks.name: Mesa Verde National Park
nationalParks.description: Protects some of the best-preserved Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites in the United States.

nationalParks.name: Arches National Park
nationalParks.description: Known for its natural sandstone arches and unique geological formations, Arches National Park offers visitors a unique and breathtaking landscape.
